articles.headline: Alibaba and Others Push to Improve Delivery, on Singles’ Day in China
articles.snippet: The country’s largest Internet merchants are working to improve logistics in China, a country plagued by delivery inefficiency.
articles.abstract: The country’s largest Internet merchants are working to improve logistics in China, a country plagued by delivery inefficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — It’s the biggest shopping day of the year in China, and the discounts are steep. But Jiang Shan waited to buy some of what she wants.
articles.byline: By Shanshan Wang and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Chief Defends Spotify After Snub by Taylor Swift
articles.snippet: The decision by Ms. Swift to remove her entire catalog from Spotify has intensified a debate over royalties paid by streaming music services.
articles.abstract: The decision by Ms. Swift to remove her entire catalog from Spotify has intensified a debate over royalties paid by streaming music services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Spotify is the future. Spotify is the enemy. Spotify doesn’t pay enough. Spotify is music’s best bet for revenue growth.

articles.headline: Net Neutrality Debate: Internet Access and Costs Are Top Issues
articles.snippet: After President Obama urged the F.C.C. to set tougher net neutrality rules, questions loom about decreased competition and the cost of monitoring.
articles.abstract: After President Obama urged the F.C.C. to set tougher net neutrality rules, questions loom about decreased competition and the cost of monitoring.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is the problem with the Internet in the United States?

articles.headline: At Afghan Border, Graft Is Part of the Bargain
articles.snippet: Afghan and foreign officials say that corruption can no longer be described as a cancer on the system: It is the system.
articles.abstract: Afghan and foreign officials say that corruption can no longer be described as a cancer on the system: It is the system.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORKHAM, Afghanistan — Some call them “the men who sit on golden chairs” — Afghan customs officials who preside over a vast ecosystem of bribery that stretches from dusty border crossings to the capital.

articles.headline: U.S. and China Reach Climate Accord After Months of Talks
articles.snippet: The deal, the signature achievement of President Obama’s state visit to China, could galvanize efforts to negotiate a new global agreement.
articles.abstract: The deal, the signature achievement of President Obama’s state visit to China, could galvanize efforts to negotiate a new global agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China and the United States made common cause on Wednesday against the threat of climate change, staking out an ambitious joint plan to curb carbon emissions as a way to spur nations around the world to make their own cuts in greenhouse gases.

articles.headline: In Net Neutrality Push, Internet Giants on the Sidelines
articles.snippet: Companies like Facebook and Google have stayed away from mobilizing their users to support an issue that primarily affects smaller Internet upstarts.
articles.abstract: Companies like Facebook and Google have stayed away from mobilizing their users to support an issue that primarily affects smaller Internet upstarts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s giant companies have been quiet lately on the question of whether the government should protect an open Internet, which they’ve previously argued is vital to innovation. Don’t count on them staking out a stronger position even though President Obama has stepped into the fray, and Washington looks to be gearing up for an epic battle over the rules that govern the Internet.

articles.headline: U.S. Bishops Struggle to Follow Lead of Francis
articles.snippet: American bishops say they can feel change rattling the church hierarchy even if they do not yet understand where the pope is leading them.
articles.abstract: American bishops say they can feel change rattling the church hierarchy even if they do not yet understand where the pope is leading them.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — It was a hail and farewell moment at a tumultuous time for the Roman Catholic Church. More than 200 bishops rose to their feet Monday and gave a protracted standing ovation to Cardinal Francis George, a former president of the bishops’ conference, who will step down next week as the archbishop of Chicago.

articles.headline: Detroit Emerges From Bankruptcy, Yet Pension Risks Linger
articles.snippet: A deal to keep Detroit’s pension system funded leaves the bankrupt city vulnerable to future fiscal crises.
articles.abstract: A deal to keep Detroit’s pension system funded leaves the bankrupt city vulnerable to future fiscal crises.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the judge in Detroit’s historic bankruptcy case approved the city’s exit plan on Friday, he said the deal Detroit cut with its retirees bordered on “miraculous.”

articles.headline: Walmart Memo Orders Stores to Improve Grocery Performance
articles.snippet: The company issued an “urgent agenda” memo to managers, pushing them to improve performance on fresh items, reflecting customer complaints about food quality.
articles.abstract: The company issued an “urgent agenda” memo to managers, pushing them to improve performance on fresh items, reflecting customer complaints about food quality.
articles.lead_paragraph: VALLEY STREAM, N.Y. — The dairy section in the Walmart supercenter here, just across the border from Queens, was sparsely stocked. Some gallon jugs of milk were dented, others soiled with what looked like dirt. The meat aisle had run out of ground beef patties and strip steak, and residue streaked some shelves.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Hitting at Heart of Hollywood, the Palm Takes Down Its Stars
articles.snippet: The restaurant, known for featuring celebrity caricatures, is opening at a new location in Beverly Hills, and leaving its famous portraits behind.
articles.abstract: The restaurant, known for featuring celebrity caricatures, is opening at a new location in Beverly Hills, and leaving its famous portraits behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Power in Hollywood is still signaled by who sits where at a handful of watering holes, but restaurant real estate as status symbol is fleeting: Lose that studio chairmanship on Monday, say hello to Siberia on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Big Banks Are Fined $4.25 Billion in Inquiry Into Currency-Rigging
articles.snippet: The fines come as regulators are increasingly targeting a business culture in the financial industry that they say encourages improper conduct by its employees.
articles.abstract: The fines come as regulators are increasingly targeting a business culture in the financial industry that they say encourages improper conduct by its employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: The traders called themselves “the players” and “the three musketeers” as they joined forces and shared information to “double team” their clients and manipulate currency rates.
articles.byline: By Chad Bray, Jenny Anderson and Ben Protess
